description:
Sitodiplosis mosellana, commonly known as the wheat midge or orange wheat blossom midge, is a species of gall midge belonging to the family Cecidomyiidae. It is a significant pest of wheat crops in many parts of the world.

Description:
- Adult Sitodiplosis mosellana is a small, delicate fly with a body length of 2-3 mm.
- The adults have orange-colored bodies and transparent wings.
- The larvae are small, legless, and orange-colored. They feed on the developing wheat kernels, causing significant yield losses.
- The life cycle of Sitodiplosis mosellana typically involves one generation per year, with the larvae overwintering in the soil and emerging as adults in the spring or early summer.
- The adults mate, and the females lay their eggs on the wheat flowers or developing wheat heads. The larvae then hatch and burrow into the wheat kernels, feeding on the developing grain.

Significance:
- Sitodiplosis mosellana is considered a major pest of wheat crops in many regions, including North America, Europe, and Asia.
- The feeding of the larvae on the wheat kernels can lead to significant yield losses, often ranging from 10-30% or more in severe infestations.
- Effective management strategies for Sitodiplosis mosellana include the use of resistant wheat cultivars, crop rotation, and the application of appropriate insecticides during the critical stages of the wheat crop.
